odoo.data:
SQL Test general one_page
60 scoring_without_answers 80.0 open
1. Which of the following query would display all the students whose first name starts with the character ‘A’? simple_choice
A. select first_name from students where first_name like ‘A%’;
2.5
B. select first_name from students where first_name like ‘%A’;
0.0
C. select first_name from students where first_name like ‘%A%’;
0.0
D. select first_name from students where first_name like ‘A’;
0.0
2. What is returned by MOD(1000,30)? simple_choice
A. 33
0.0
B. 30
0.0
C. 3
0.0
D. 10
2.5
3. You want to calculate the tax payable by the employees of an organization. If the employee gets a commission, then the tax would be calculated on commission plus salary, if the employee does not get any commission, then the tax would be calculated on salary only. Which function should you use for calculating tax? simple_choice
A. NVL
0.0
B. NVL2
2.5
C. NULLIF
0.0
D. COALESCE
0.0
4. Which of the following is true about a group function? simple_choice
A. Group functions operate on sets of rows to produce multiple results per group
0.0
B. DISTINCT keyword makes a group function consider duplicate values
0.0
C. Group functions ignore null values
2.5
D. None of the above
0.0
5. Which of the following is not true about the COUNT function? simple_choice
A. COUNT(*) returns the number of rows in the table
0.0
B. COUNT(exp) returns the number of rows with non-null values for the exp
0.0
C. COUNT(DISTINCT exp) returns the number of unique, non-null values in the column
0.0
D. All are true
2.5
6. In which of the following cases a DML statement is not executed? simple_choice
A. When existing rows are modified
0.0
B. When some rows are deleted
0.0
C. When a table is deleted
2.5
D. All of the above
0.0
7. Which of the following is NOT true about the SQL transaction control statements? simple_choice
A. The COMMIT statement ends the current transaction and makes all data changes permanent
0.0
B. The ROLLBACK statement ends the transaction and discards all the pending data changes
0.0
C. Each DML statement is automatically committed
2.5
D. All are true
0.0
8. Which of the following is not true about creating constraints? simple_choice
A. Constraints are defined using the CREATE CONSTRAINT statement
2.5
B. They are created at the same time when the table is created
0.0
C. They could be created after the table is created
0.0
D. All the constraints are stored in data dictionary
0.0
9. Which of the following is not true about the Pseudocolumns that return the sequence values? simple_choice
A. NEXTVAL returns the next available sequence value
0.0
B. CURRVAL gets the current sequence value
0.0
C. PREVVAL gets the previous sequence value
2.5
D. None of the above
0.0
10. Which of the following is not true about database synonyms? simple_choice
A. Synonyms are used for shortening lengthy object names
0.0
B. A synonym is just an alternative name
0.0
C. Synonyms can be created for tables, views, sequences, procedures and other database objects
0.0
D. None of the above
2.5

C. INFORMATION_SCHEMA.DOMAIN_CONSTRAINTS

A. UNIQUE

B. NOT NULL

C. CHECK

13. Which of the reasons will force you to use the XML data model in SQL Server? simple_choice
A. Order is inherent in your data
0.0
B. Your data is sparse or you do not know the structure of the data
0.0
C. Your data represents containment hierarchy
0.0
D. All of the Mentioned

A. Control-of-flow language

B. Flow language

C. Control language
0.0
D. None of the mentioned

15. Which of the following statements is true? simple_choice
A. DELETE does not free the space containing the table and TRUNCATE free the space containing the table
2.5
B. Both DELETE and TRUNCATE free the space containing the table
0.0
C. Both DELETE and TRUNCATE does not free the space containing the table
0.0
D. DELETE free the space containing the table and TRUNCATE does not free the space containing the table
0.0
16. With SQL, how do you select all the records from a table named “Persons” where the value of the column “FirstName” ends with an “a”? simple_choice
A. SELECT * FROM Persons WHERE FirstName=’a’
0.0
B. SELECT * FROM Persons WHERE FirstName LIKE ‘a%’
0.0
C. SELECT * FROM Persons WHERE FirstName LIKE ‘%a’
2.5
D. SELECT * FROM Persons WHERE FirstName=’%a%’
0.0
17. With SQL, how can you return all the records from a table named “Persons” sorted descending by “FirstName”? simple_choice
A. SELECT * FROM Persons SORT BY ‘FirstName’ DESC
0.0
B. SELECT * FROM Persons ORDER FirstName DESC
0.0
C. SELECT * FROM Persons SORT ‘FirstName’ DESC
0.0
D. SELECT * FROM Persons ORDER BY FirstName DESC
2.5
18. With SQL, how can you return the number of not null records in the “Persons” table? simple_choice
A. SELECT COUNT() FROM Persons
2.5
B. SELECT COLUMNS() FROM Persons
0.0
C. SELECT COLUMNS(*) FROM Persons
0.0
D. SELECT COUNT(*) FROM Persons
0.0
19. What does the ALTER TABLE clause do? simple_choice
A. The SQL ALTER TABLE clause modifies a table definition by altering, adding, or deleting table columns and/or constraints
2.5
B. The SQL ALTER TABLE clause is used to insert data into database table
0.0
C. THE SQL ALTER TABLE deletes data from database table
0.0
D. The SQL ALTER TABLE clause is used to delete a database table
0.0
20. How can you change “Hansen” into “Nilsen” in the “LastName” column in the Persons table? simple_choice
A. UPDATE Persons SET LastName=’Hansen’ INTO LastName=’Nilsen’
0.0
B. MODIFY Persons SET LastName=’Nilsen’ WHERE LastName=’Hansen’
0.0
C. MODIFY Persons SET LastName=’Hansen’ INTO LastName=’Nilsen’
0.0
D. UPDATE Persons SET LastName=’Nilsen’ WHERE LastName=’Hansen’
2.5
21. Find all the cities with temperature, condition and humidity whose humidity is in the range of 63 to 79. simple_choice
A. SELECT * FROM weather WHERE humidity IN (63 to 79)
0.0
B. SELECT * FROM weather WHERE humidity NOT IN (63 AND 79)
0.0
C. SELECT * FROM weather WHERE humidity BETWEEN 63 AND 79
2.5
D. SELECT * FROM weather WHERE humidity NOT BETWEEN 63 AND 79
0.0
22. Find all the tuples having a temperature greater than ‘Paris’. simple_choice
A. SELECT * FROM weather WHERE temperature > (SELECT temperature FROM weather WHERE city = ‘Paris’
2.5
B. SELECT * FROM weather WHERE temperature > (SELECT * FROM weather WHERE city = ‘Paris’)
0.0
C. SELECT * FROM weather WHERE temperature > (SELECT city FROM weather WHERE city = ‘Paris’)
0.0
D. SELECT * FROM weather WHERE temperature > ‘Paris’ temperature
0.0

B. Acts like a WHERE clause but is used for rows rather than columns.
0.0
C. Acts like a WHERE clause but is used for columns rather than groups.
0.0
D. Acts EXACTLY like a WHERE clause.

37. Which of the following statements is correct regarding the difference between TRUNCATE, DELETE and DROP command? simple_choice
DELETE operation can be rolled back but TRUNCATE and DROP operations cannot be rolled back.
TRUNCATE and DROP operations can be rolled back but DELETE operations cannot be rolled back.
DELETE is an example of DML, but TRUNCATE and DROP are examples of DDL.
All are examples of DDL.
A. 1 and 3
2.5
B. 2 and 3
0.0
C. 2 and 4
0.0
D. 1 and 4
0.0
38. Which of the following can replace the below query? simple_choice
A. Select Name,ID from Courses, Student where Student_ID = ID;
0.0
B. Select Name, ID from Student natural join Courses;
2.5
C. Select Name, ID from Student;
0.0
D. Select ID from Student join Courses;
0.0

40. Table Employee has 10 records. It has a non-NULL SALARY column which is also UNIQUE. The SQL statement simple_choice
SELECT COUNT(*) FROM Employee WHERE SALARY > ANY (SELECT SALARY FROM EMPLOYEE);
prints
A. 10
0.0
B. 9
2.5
C. 5
0.0
D. 0
